{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the information provided, the male partner has a low semen volume (0.8 ml per ejaculate) and absent fructose, with no sperm seen under the microscope. This suggests a possible ejaculatory duct obstruction or congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens. To further evaluate this, the next step would be to perform a per-rectal examination to check for ejaculatory duct obstruction. This can help determine if there is a physical blockage preventing the release of semen.
